instructors.name: Junior Bontognali
instructors.shortBio: Junior B. is a mobile developer working in the industry since 10 years, currently working for Credit Suisse. He’s one of the early adopters of RxSwift which he contributed during the early stage of the project spreading the word about it. He recently co-autherd the book “RxSwift: Reactive Programming with Swift” published by Ray Wenderlich

instructors.name: Svetlana Isakova
instructors.shortBio: Svetlana is a Developer Advocate at JetBrains. She is been working on the Kotlin language (http://kotlinlang.org/) since 2011. She is one of the authors of the 'Kotlin in Action' book.

instructors.name: Wei-Meng Lee
instructors.shortBio: Wei-Meng Lee is a technologist and founder of Developer Learning Solutions (http://www.learn2develop.net), a technology company specializing in hands-on training on the latest mobile technologies.

100.description: In this session, you will learn how to use React Native to build cross-platform apps for iOS and Android devices. You will see how to start building your mobile app within minutes and see how live reload, hot load and live updates work.
100.title: Building Cross Platform Native Mobile Apps using React Native

101.description: Release process in Software Product Engineering has evolved into a largescale pseudo-continuous deployment even in outsourced engineering teams. What lessons did we take from our mobile-centric customers? I'll describe how we maintain release schedules, how we test and collect mobile metrics, and describe the real-world issues of dealing with package deployment and end-user uptake, particularly on the Cross-platform arena
101.title: Secret Sauce of Cross-platform Mobile App Continuous Delivery in the Outsource Industry

102.description: The next billion people going online live in emerging countries. This talk will introduce you to this subject, discuss the differences and challenges, and suggest guidelines to have in mind when developing for this ecosystem.
102.title: Developing for the Next Billion

103.description: In the last couple of years, the web has taken a quantum leap in usability, with offline support, and many ways to make the experience very app-like. So the question is unavoidable, can the web be the platform to make smart devices succeed too? The short answer is yes, so come and hear how!
103.title: The web in an era of smart devices

104.description: This talk is about how to succesfully work in a organization or team that is distributed across locations and timezones. It will cover the strategies and tools we found to work and also those that did not.
104.title: The Good, The Bad and the Ugly - Building Distributed Teams at Realm

105.description: We built a scalable, cross-platform, offline-capable app for cyclists with the Firebase realtime database. We'll cover authentication, testing security and validation rules. How to reliably integrate this with your workflow and automatic indexing/aggregating data with Firebase functions and more.
105.title: Launching Beeline with Firebase Realtime Database, Authentication and Functions

106.description:
Join me in this talk, where I would like to talk about the core principles of AAC, followed by Internal code structure of AAC libraries. With this knowledge, we will revisit MVVM and MVP to see how we can fully/partially integrate AAC libraries to address and fix the issues of lifecycle, configuration changes, state management and data persistence in an Android application. The goal of this talk is to provide a solid MVVM based architecture using AAC, with clean architecture, RxJava and Dagger.

In this talk, you will be learning:

1. Issues with view lifecycle, configuration changes, state management & data persistence.

2. Core principles of AAC in general and Internals of AAC libraries.

3. How AAC libraries help us fix the problems discussed earlier.

4. Should/Can you use AAC libraries with MVP, and up to what extent.

5. Refactoring an MVVM application to integrate AAC libraries, including AAC based utilities
106.title: Internals of Android Architecture Components & making the best use of it in MVVM and MVP

107.description: Programming is an art form, yet we often view programming as a rote act. In this talk, we’ll explore the connections between the brain, technology, and creativity. You’ll learn the benefits of creativity, how to practice it, and how you can use it to make you a better technologist.
107.title: Keynote: The Creative Technologist

109.description: Having developed several IoT apps for iOS and backends I can understand why in 2016 an army of toasters brought down the internet on the east coast. But how would you avoid that? Talking about the taxonomy of data exchange formats and design considerations, I’ll show you why IoT is great but needs your help!
109.title: The Internet of Things and iOS: Don't let your toaster bring down the internet!

110.description: Let your users be the voice talent with Actions on Google. Learn how to design, develop, and distribute rich conversational experiences with Node.js. We’ll show you how to approach voice-driven, natural language interactions with API.AI’s powerful bot platform.
110.title: Get Talking with Actions on Google

111.description: Android security is nowhere near where it should be. It's easy to hack and get sensitive information from a many different apps. In this session we will explore a number of ways an Android app can be exploited and most importantly methods that we can use to avoid these attacks.
111.title: I just hacked your app!

112.description: There is a lot of Hype with ML and AI lately, and TensorFlow is the framework of choice from Google. But as a Mobile Developer you might have asked yourself, how can I benefit from it? In this talk, you will learn your first steps into the fascinating ML world for mobile.
112.title: TensorFlow for Mobile Developers

113.description:
The async/await feature allows you to write the asynchronous code in a straightforward way, without a long list of callbacks. Used in C# for quite a while already, it has proven to be extremely useful. In Kotlin 1.1 you have async and await as library functions implemented using coroutines.

A coroutine is a light-weight thread that can be suspended and resumed later. Very precise definition, but might be confusing at first. What 'light-weight thread' means? How does suspension work? This talk uncovers the magic.

We'll discuss the concept of coroutines, the power of async/await, and how you can benefit from defining your asynchronous computations using suspend functions..
113.title: Kotlin Coroutines

114.description:
Soon after Swift became open source, Tripta moved to the backend-services team at Capital One in order to explore the use of building production-ready services in Swift. This project required her to take a nascent technology to production, which meant assessing the business goals and implementing against Swift as a platform to enable our business and streamline our development process.

Here she gained a lot of perspective, both as a general technologist and as a client-first engineer, and will share what she learned with the audience.
114.title: Enterprise Swift Services: A Recipe for Deployment into Production

115.description:
Exciting times for mixed reality enthusiasts. With many AR and VR platformsn ow available, we're witnessing the birth of a new medium. 
In many ways, this boom is similar to the personal computer revolution ofthe 70s and 80s. People are wondering: "Besides games, what are these gadgets good for, anyway?"
In this session, we'll see how people are using mixed reality for social good. Then, we'll learn about the Android Thing, Ar.js and the Daydream VR platform. We'll see how you can use these and other platforms to build your own community projects.
115.title: Mixed Reality for Social Good

116.description: At I/O this year, the Room persistence library was introduced as part of the Architecture Components effort. In this talk we'll look at what Room has to offer, why and when you should use it and how it compares to existing solutions.
116.title: Room: The official persistence library

117.description: React Native promises 85% code reuse...can it be done? In my experience, YES. But it's important to architect your code base properly. Learn how you can maximize your ability to reuse code across platforms by properly organizing and structuring your code base.
117.title: React Native code reuse: Architecture that works

118.description:
Animations make your app visually appealing, easier to use, and more engaging.

Animations however are not limited to only traditional Xamarin development; you can add beautiful animations to Xamarin.Forms.

In this session, you will learn the core concepts of when to use animations in a mobile app and explore several different frameworks used to create them.

When to properly use animations to provide visual feedback, supply context around UI elements, and call attention to app status changes will be explored. Then you’ll learn how to make your app come to life using the built-in Xamarin.Forms animation APIs, SkiaSharp, and the new Lottie animation framework from Airbnb.

After this session, you’ll be equipped to create Xamarin.Forms apps that will stand out with animations.
118.title: Animating Xamarin.Forms

119.description:
Hybrid mobile app development has come a long way in recent years, to the point that many, if not most, types of applications can be built with standard Web technologies.

We will review what the Web has to offer in 2017 and how Ionic and Angular can help building world class applications on many platforms with only Web technologies.
119.title: Code once, deploy everywhere with Ionic

120.description: Apple Watch is an exciting new platform, but many app developers didn't think through the user experience before rushing to the platform. AtRunkeeper, we've been committed to our Apple Watch experience since day one, and we've kept it on the cutting edge of watchOS since then. In this talk, you will learn all the lessons we've learned along the way: the technical challenges of watch development, the changes we've made to the experienc ealong the way, and how you can change the way you think about Apple Watch to create a great app for your users.
120.title: Building a Meaningful Apple Watch Experience

121.description: Connecting to smart locks, light bulbs and alarm systems can be a pain. Learn what I did wrong and other experiences to make it more pleasurable with Swift, iOS and Functional Reactive Programming.
121.title: Second degree asyncronousity - learnings from developing iOS + IoT apps

122.description: Come and be inspired as Chris shares  the two year journey of his team on how they increased productivity, reduced friction and created a UI framework abstraction on top of the native Cocoa framework.
122.title: func inspiration() -> production

123.description:
In addition to building Android apps with the standard Java-based platform provided by Google, you now have the option to code in Javascript or C# through React Native and Xamarin. What do these platforms have in common and where do they differ? Which should you choose?

In this talk I will demonstrate how to build a simple news paper article presenter using the VG.no back-end in three different technologies. The talk will cover common use cases such as network communication, state handling and lifecycle management.
123.title: Three technology options for building native Android apps

124.description: We are working with Coinbase to create Toshi; an instant messaging app with the ability to painlessly send money across the globe. The app is simple, but the technology behind it is not. We create a cryptographically secure wallet on the device, broadcast money transfers on the Ethereum blockchain, and send messages encrypted using the Signal protocol. Join this talk to learn about cryptocurrencies, what they are, how they work, and what they can be used for.
124.title: Cryptocurrency - building a wallet on your phone

125.description:
GraphQL is a strongly-typed and efficient method for fetching structured data from a server, designed to be an alternative to REST. It was developed in 2012 at Facebook, and has powered Facebook's main iOS and Android apps for the last five years. After being open sourced in 2015, it is now being used by an increasing number of well known companies.

In this talk, Martijn will introduce GraphQL, discuss why it is such a great match for mobile development, and talk about his efforts to build an open source GraphQL client for iOS, written in Swift.
125.title: Improving the architecture of your iOS app with GraphQL

126.description: Most mobile applications rely on the traditional request response paradigm for communicating with the server. However, modern apps demand more. Likes and comments stream in as you watch a Periscope video or read a Facebook post. Typing indicators tell you whether your friend is typing a response back to you on iMessage. In this talk, I will share best practices, tools and methodologies for pushing realtime content to mobile devices from our experiences while building Realtime Messaging at LinkedIn.
126.title: Realtime Content Delivery: Powering dynamic instant experiences on your mobile apps

127.description: In this talk we’ll understand how Kotlin isn’t just syntactic sugar, it’s a better way to build Android apps. We will start with a modern java-based Android project and walk through a complete migration to Kotlin. In the process, you will see objective examples of how the Android concepts you're already familiar with are expressed in Kotlin more accurately, with less code, and with far fewer chances for bugs!
127.title: Pragmatic Kotlin on Android

128.description: At SpotHero, we've been moving our entire iOS application to Swift and have started moving our Android app to Kotlin. We'd like to share what we've learned, so you can take advantage of the improvements while avoiding some of the pitfalls we ran into, so you can decide what works best for your team.
128.title: Lessons learned from porting to Swift and Kotlin

129.description: How hard can responsive web be? It sounds simple: design for a number of screen sizes and just throw in several media queries and your website isnow "responsive"! Unfortunately, this is not the case and responsive web hasn't made our job easier. Adopting responsive web design will force you to change your design, development, and testing workflow. Problems may also arise in different stages of the workflow. In this talk, we will talk about responsive web blunders at Viki, how we overcome it, and some tips on how you can avoid it.
129.title: Responsive Web Bloopers at Viki

130.description: In this presentation, Igor will show case studies about the toolset used (CI, Bugtracker, Wiki, etc) for development. He will explain how they help or undermine good initiatives in companies and what can do to improve
130.title: Tools We Use: Their Design and Influence

131.description: The first question after people have learned about how to implement anadvanced architecture in their applications from scratch is: "How do I transform my codebase from its current state to a well architected app?" Forget about BigBang rewrites. Come and learn some strategies, tricks, and gotchas about how to do the migration to an advanced arch mobile app. Move to from Objective-C to Swift in the process and keep it functional during the whole process.
131.title: Refactor Your Way Forward

132.description: How to leverage PWA on your front-end framework?
132.title: PWA & Front-end Frameworks

133.description: Progressive Web Apps are the return of the web and the first proper contender to native applications. Take your web products and make them work offline, get notification options and keep them up-to-date without pestering the user.
133.title: Keynote: Progressive Web Apps

134.description: Layout is a framework for implementing iOS user interfaces using runtime-evaluated XML template files. It is intended as a more-or-less drop-in replacement for Nibs and Storyboards, but offers a number of advantages. It's simpler for simple layouts, more powerful for complex layouts, easier to collaborate on and debug. To make this possible Layout introduces a new node hierarchy for managing views, similar to the 'Virtual DOM' used by React Native.
134.title: The Layout Framework

135.description: A lot has happened with Fuse since last year’s (very) popular presentation at Mobile Era and in this session we’ll take a look at some of the hottest news in everybody’s favourite framework.
135.title: Fuse - still an awesome platform for apps development?

136.description: Benedicte and Erik share their experience using Ionic 2 for the app version of varsom.no. The good, the bad, and what future offerings from Ionic we eagerly await.
136.title: Serving the Norwegian people with Ionic 2

137.description: This talk offers a lightning quick overview of GraphQL, a query language for APIs, and how we used it in our Progressive Web App.
137.title: GET what you need and drop the REST

138.description: In this talk I will guide you to MVVM comparing to other architectures I've tried. It explains the best practices for structuring source code and dealing with asynchronicity. This will make you regret not using reactive programming earlier.
138.title: A taste of MVVM + RxSwift

139.description: Yr is the world's 5th largest weather service. Adored by millons, hated by commercial weather networks, used by weather frustrated Norwegians as well as farmers in South Africa, and being a service for the people funded by the people. Yr is trying to redefine how people view the weather, with world class weather visualization, A LOT of prototyping and crazy ideas. I'm here to talk about our awesome journey, the techy details and the painstaking process of working with a really hetrogenous user group.
139.title: Yr - The next generation weather visualization

140.description: Making apps accessible for everyone is important both to make sure you reach the largest user base possible and so you do not discriminate against people with disabilities. It can even enable additional features, like navigation with voice commands. But accessibility does not happen by itself! In this talk I will show you the techniques you should use to increase the accessibility of your Android apps, and warn you against a few common pitfalls.
140.title: The Secrets of Android Accessibility

141.description: Tired of tedious time reporting? This talk will give you a glimpse into how Visma is streamlining the everyday work tasks such as filing expenses, reporting hours and register absence. The results is impacting most employees in Northern Europe, perhaps even you.
141.title: Workflows First

142.description: Beta groups are a joy for lazy test managers. Letting the users do the testwork is a fascinating approach. We can develop short stories do a lighttest and let the Beta group do its work. Working with production releases and beta releases simultaniously also gives us an edge!
142.title: The use of Beta groups to help improve the product

143.description:
Instant Apps is a bridge between mobile web and native apps. It absorbs the best of both worlds and provides a unique user experience. Instant Apps was designed with speed, light weight, best UX and modularity in mind. Just like mobile web apps Instant Apps is very light and does not require installation. On the other hand, it provides a truly native user experience with material design and native navigation, which users are so used to.

Building Instant Apps requires a lot of work on the architecture side, modularization and reducing the app size. Instant Apps types, architecture changes, size and feature constraints, practical tips to slim down the application, lessons learnt will be discussed during the talk.
143.title: Make Your App Instant!

144.description: Continuous integration and deployment is the working tool for a sales force in 22 different countries. A talk about how we outgrew detailed specifications and rigid structures, and replaced them with transparency and a better common understanding of what we are trying to do accomplish, and the tools we are using. Most importantly; what we have learned about reducing friction.
144.title: Working with sharp tools - A case study of Continuous deployment

901.description: It's time to power up ourselves!
901.title: Lunch

speakers.name: Christian Heilmann
speakers.shortBio: Chris Heilmann dedicated the last 20 years of his life to make the web work and thrive. As a lead developer on some of the largest web products he learned that knowledge is not enough without teamwork and good handover. He dedicated most of his time since on educating, writing and sharing, presenting on average at 30 conferences a year. He strives to make code and coders work efficiently and get more done quickly without losing the understanding of what we do. He is the author of several JavaScript books and the Developer Evangelism handbook (http://developer-evangelism.com). He is currently a Senior Program Manager in Microsoft and spends a lot of time pondering how machine learning and AI can aid humans and replace jobs we're too important to do.

speakers.name: Corey Latislaw
speakers.shortBio: Corey Leigh Latislaw is a Google Developer Expert in Android who has written several high profile Android applications at companies large and small. By day, she runs an Android consulting firm where she writes native Android apps and manages Android developers. At night, she authors videos and books on Android programming.

speakers.name: Aaron Greenwald
speakers.shortBio: Before mobile development with React Native existed, Aaron architected and built web apps using AngularJS and other web development tech. Now he’s part of the team building Wix’s mobile presence, and is focused on delivering first-class experiences to users who need their business to be mobile. He enjoys talking, especially about software.

speakers.name: Julien Renaux
speakers.shortBio: Julien is a front-end Mobile Engineer with experience working for startups and multinationals across the world. Angular, Ionic and React enthusiastiche spends most of his free time writing on his blog, working on open source projects or organizing Google Developer Group meetups.

speakers.name: Jorge D. Ortiz-Fuentes
speakers.shortBio: Jorge is a freelance dedicated to mobile development, security, and systems architecture. As a developer he started to work for the M.I.T. in 1993 and since he has collaborated in many software projects. Most of them were internally for HP where he worked for more than 15 years. Since 2008 he has been working in different aspects of mobile development. After playing with PalmOS, he learned Android programming for the first Google App contest and immediately started to play with the first iPhone SDK. He often participates as instructor in the best iOS and Android Bootcamps in USA and Europe. He founded Canonical Examples in 2015 to help other developers to take a step forward and become senior developers in a very demanding market.

speakers.name: Mike Oliver
speakers.shortBio: Mike Oliver is the VP of Product Engineering at Runkeeper. He has been working with mobile for his entire career; whether 10 years ago on a spinach-screen Blackberry or today on iPhone and Android. He is constantly always amazed at what's possible with the tiny computers in our pockets. He works building out the mobile team at Runkeeper, and they continue to build a cutting edge app at the intersection of fitness and technology. He loves sharing his passion with others and helping people learn. This has leda him to becoming a Tech Editor on raywenderlich.com.

speakers.name: Ellen Shapiro
speakers.shortBio: She is the lead mobile developer at SpotHero, running both the iOS and Android teams as they work to make parking easier across the US and Canada. She has been developing for both iOS and Android professionally since 2011, and she writes and edits tutorials for both iOS and Android for RayWenderlich.com.

speakers.name: Viraj Tank
speakers.shortBio: Viraj has been working on the Android platform since the start, and is currently working at Sociomantic Labs, Berlin as Mobile Lead. He started his journey with the Android platform by porting a native libraries, slowly moving to the Java framework and is currently developing Applications. When not working on Android stuff, he enjoys playing Age of Empires II.

speakers.name: Natalie Pistunovich
speakers.shortBio: Natalie is the co-founder of Connta, a platform for running an online storefrom a mobile phone that is focused on emerging countries, based in Nairobi. Prior to that she worked in the mobile industry in Berlin for 3.5 years, where her last position was a Backend Engineer at adjust - a mobile attribution and analytics company. She graduated with a B.Sc. in Computer and Software Engineering from the Technion, Israel, while working as a Silicon Integration Engineer at Intel. In her free time she is co-leading the Berlin chapters of Google Developer Groups Golang and Women Techmakers, volunteering with the Tunapanda coding school in Nairobi and sailing.

speakers.name: Josh Skeen
speakers.shortBio: Josh Skeen is an Android engineer and instructor at Big Nerd Ranch, an app development consulting and training company located in Atlanta, GA USA. When not working on client consulting projects, Josh teaches the Android Essentials bootcamp and enjoys researching new ways to use Gradle and RxJava and developing skills for Amazon's Alexa. When not in front of his computer, you can find Josh running, practicing yoga, or creating electronic music.

speakers.name: Håkon Bogen
speakers.shortBio: Håkon Bogen has worked as an iOS developer for  six years with experience on working on some of the most known apps in Norway. Currently he is CTO at Beining & Bogen where he is working on several different IoT apps. He is also a lecturing a course on iOS development at Westerdals ACT. He really enjoys functional reactive programming, server side swift and writing testable apps in with short iterations.

speakers.name: Chetan Padia
speakers.shortBio: Chetas is build a cross-platform app, firmware and hardware for cyclists at Beeline. He is interested in testing and quality of software and formerly worked as an engineer at SwiftKey.

speakers.name: Matthew Soucoup
speakers.shortBio: Matthew Soucoup is a Xamarin and Microsoft MVP and the author of a Pluralsight course on Xamarin.Forms. Matt speaks regularly across the United States on Xamarin and mobile development. He founded a company, Code Mill Technologies, that focuses on cross platform development and blogs regularly.

speakers.name: Majid Hajian
speakers.shortBio: Majid is a Software engineer working at Futurehome.no, an IoT startup. He is passionate about front-end and mobiledevelopment and loves creating amazing user experiences. Beside front-end, he enjoys coding with Node.js, Golang, Rust and Ruby on Rails.

speakers.name: Frode Nilsen
speakers.shortBio: Frode is Tech Lead at Schibsted Product & Tech and also works as an Android developer. He and his team works with apps for some of the largest online news papers in Norway and Sweden: VG.no, Aftonbladet and Aftenposten. Frode has been working full time with Android apps for five years and other mobile platforms longer. Before app-development he was busy consulting on the Microsoft platform for different companies in the banking and health care industry in Oslo.

speakers.name: Christoffer Winterkvist
speakers.shortBio: Chris started doing OS X development back in 2010, started doing iOS backin 2014, these days he is chief puppet for the technology team at@hyperoslo. He does a lot of open source development both at work and inhis spare time. He also likes poetry and long walks on the beach.

speakers.name: Hugo Visser
speakers.shortBio: Hugo is a software engineer who has worked on enterprise, desktop and mobile software products. Since the introduction of Android he has been steadily focussing on developing for Android only, resulting in his first app in 2009. Hugo has released several open source libraries and tools to help him and other developers build better software. He’s a Google Developer Expert for Android and one of the organizers of the Dutch Android User Group. With his company Little Robots, he focuses on smart use of Android in every possible way.

speakers.name: Wei-Meng Lee
speakers.shortBio: Wei-Meng Lee is a technologist and founder of Developer Learning Solutions (http://www.learn2develop.net), a technology company specializing in hands-on training on the latest mobile technologies.

speakers.name: Marcos Placona
speakers.shortBio:
Marcos is a developer evangelist at Twilio where he works with communities in London and all over Europe. He is passionate about technology and security and spends a great deal of his time building mobile and web apps, and often connecting them to physical devices.

Marcos is also a Google Developer Expert and a great believer in open source projects. When he’s not writing open source code, he’s probably blogging about code on https://androidsecurity.info or https://androidthings.rocks.

He’s also a great API enthusiast and believes they bring peace to the Software Engineering world.

speakers.name: Etienne Caron
speakers.shortBio: Etienne Caron is an Android developer at Shopify, a popular canadian e-commerce company. He is also part of Google's Developer Expert program, and an instructor for Caster.io. 3D animation, procedural content generation and VR are some of his hobbies, and he loves introducing other developers to this fascinating field.

speakers.name: Tripta Gupta
speakers.shortBio: Tripta Gupta is an iOS software engineer at Capital One in San Francisco. She likes to be   at the intersection of technology, business, and creativity. Hobbies that   she’s passionate about are endurance running, supporting diversity and   inclusion, and storytelling as a medium to create resonance with people.

speakers.name: Akhilesh Gupta
speakers.shortBio: Akhilesh is the technical lead for the LinkedIn mobile messaging products. For the past year, he has been working on the revamp of LinkedIn’s messaging offerings to instant, realtime messaging on its mobile apps. Before this, he was the head of engineering for the Ride Experience program  at Uber Technologies in San Francisco where he led a large team of backend,  web, iOS and Android engineers to build delightful mobile products and   infrastructure for the core Uber rider application. He holds a Masters degree in CS from Stanford University.

speakers.name: Christian Melchior
speakers.shortBio: Christian is the Android Team Lead at Realm and is focused on making Realm's Android SDK the default choice for developers. He has a strong love for clean, approachable code that's fast to boot. He has been working remotely for the last 3 years, building the Android team from 2 in one place to 7 in as many locations.

speakers.name: Pearl Latteier
speakers.shortBio: Pearl Latteier is a software engineer at Bendyworks in Madison WI. She builds JavaScript applications for web and mobile, and she has spoken at conferences around the world on topics including Progressive Web Apps, Web Components, and Polymer. Before becoming a software developer, Pearl earned a PhD in from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, where for five years she  taught courses in the Department of Communication Arts.

speakers.name: Abraham Williams
speakers.shortBio: An experienced developer, start-up founder, and international speaker, Abraham Williams brings a broad range of skills to his current role as a senior developer at Bendyworks. A top 1% contributor at Stack Overflow and an active member of Google Developer Groups, Abraham has been recognized by Google as a Developer Expert for his ability to identify technology problems and provide quality solutions in the community. He is also a returning speaker to this year's Mobile Era.

speakers.name: Kenneth Rohde Christiansen
speakers.shortBio: Kenneth Rohde Christiansen is a Danish software engineer and architect who specializes in mobile and web technology. Working at Intel out of Copenhagen, Kenneth helps define Intel’s strategy and plans regarding the Web Platform, as well as puts it into action. Before joining Intel, Kenneth was employed by Nokia (Denmark and Brazil) where he worked on the Nokia N9 web browser, Qt, WebKit, as well as many other mobile projects. Currently working on Progressive Web Apps and emerging web standards like the Web App Manifest, Generic Sensors, Web NFC etc.

speakers.name: Enrique Lopez Manas
speakers.shortBio: Enrique López Mañas is a Google Developer Expert and independent IT consultant. He has been working with mobile technologies and learning from them since 2007. He is an avid contributor to the open source community and a FLOSS (Free Libre Open Source Software) kind of guy, being among the top 10 open source Java contributors in Germany. He is also a part of the Google LaunchPad accelerator, where he participates in Google global initiatives to influence hundreds of the best startups from all around the globe. In his free time he rides his bike, take pictures, and travel until the point of exhaustion. He also writes literature and enjoys all kinds of arts. He likes to write about himself in third person.

speakers.name: Kosala Nuwan Perera
speakers.shortBio: He is a high profile Solution Architect, Hybrid Mobile Developer, User Experience and Startup Advisor with broad experience and knowledge in the software development outsourcing/offshoring industry. He has worked on various platforms and development tools with a primary focus on the Mobile, Web, and .NET platform. Kosala has worked for some major clients in Sri Lanka, Australia, Sweden and Norway.

speakers.name: Aysha Anggraini
speakers.shortBio: Aysha is a front-end engineer and wannabe designer at Viki, where she works closely with the UX team in order to build functional and beautiful UIs on viki.com and Viki's internal tools. When she is not super busy (which is rare these days), she either writes about geeky stuff on her blog renaysha.me or builds experimental and pretty things on CodePen (codepen.io/rrenula). She loves design, gaming, dancing, and Yoga.

speakers.name: Igor Mandrigin
speakers.shortBio: Igor is a software engineer since 10 years, and has spent the last 4 years in mobile development for both iOS and Android. He is currently employed as a Team Leader for Opera for Android.

speakers.name: Florian Harr
speakers.shortBio: Florian Harr wants to help you build beautiful apps. He has six years experience building iOS apps and backend systems in multi-platform teams. He has shared this knowledge in the classroom and at conferences the world over. He is happy to tackle new software domains and challenge existing approaches.

speakers.name: Svetlana Isakova
speakers.shortBio: Svetlana is a Developer Advocate at JetBrains. She is been working on the Kotlin language (http://kotlinlang.org/) since 2011. She is one of the authors of the 'Kotlin in Action' book.

speakers.name: Colin Dodd
speakers.shortBio: Colin has been an android developer for five years and is still learning new things every day. Previously worked at Sony, BBC and appear.in. Now he is turning ideas into reality at Bakken & Bæck

speakers.name: Martijn Walraven
speakers.shortBio: Martijn Walraven lives in Amsterdam and works remotely as an open source developer at Meteor / Apollo. He is focused on bringing GraphQL to mobile developers, and is the creator of a strongly-typed, caching GraphQL client for iOS written in Swift.

speakers.name: Nick Lockwood
speakers.shortBio: Nick Lockwood is an avid open source contributer and has created many of the most popular libraries for iOS. He is currently employed at Schibsted and his latest framework, Layout, was created to solve the unique problems presented when managing a conglomerate of apps.

speakers.name: Remi Pedersen
speakers.shortBio: Remi works with Fuse - building tools for mobile app developers and designers. Back in the dark ages he was at Falanx and ARM, developing the “Mali” brand of graphics accelerators which have shipped in over a billion mobile devices by now. He’s been programming for over 25 years and has even more experience talking and gesticulating (something he’ll happily do about subjects such as the demoscene, startups, and HW & SW tech). Late at night he still codes demos for his trusty old Amiga 500.

speakers.name: Benedicte Raae
speakers.shortBio: Benedicte is a Web/app developer experienced in working with Ionic 2. She is enganged in a client project for the Norwegian Water Resources and Energy Directorate.

speakers.name: Glenn Ricaud
speakers.shortBio: Glenn is a software engineer working mostly in middleware and currently employed at Enonic. In his spare time, he enjoys creating frameworks and tools.

speakers.name: Khoa Pham
speakers.shortBio: Khoa is an iOS developer at Hyper, where he makes awesome apps and participates in open source development. He is a great fan of reactive programming, and you should talk to him about it!

speakers.name: Thomas Pettersen
speakers.shortBio: I am the Tech Lead mobility @ Netcompany. I have worked with Android and web applications for seven years, with some of the coolest apps on the market. I really enjoy the rapidly evolving technology the mobile world experiencing today. My other passion is experimenting with food and giving cooking classes to my colleagues and friends

speakers.name: Vegard Haugstvedt
speakers.shortBio: Vegard is a frontend developer with backend tendencies. He presentedoffline first-apps with Couchbase Mobile last year, and is now back toexplain accessibility in Android apps.

speakers.name: Atle Myhrer Knudtzon
speakers.shortBio: Atle currently works as a development manager in Visma at their headquarters in Oslo, where he is heading mobile development in the Enterprise division. Building on top of experiences from previous startup projects he is also leading the implementation of the lean startup methodology throughout the organization.

speakers.name: Haavard Gulbrandsen
speakers.shortBio: Haavard is a test manager and been involved in testing apps for multiple platforms for the past 5-6 years. Mobile technology fascinates me even though I can not programme aline!

speakers.name: Yuliya Kaleda
speakers.shortBio: Yuliya is an Android developer, leading a team of four developers at Jet.com. Her main focus is to build performant, scalable, cutting-edge Android projects. Her most recent project was the first multi-feature Instant App, which was a huge success and got featured on the Google Android Developer website. She is a member of C4Q - non-profit organization, which fosters the tech community in NY. She also volunteers in Access Code Program (Android Development), which targets underrepresented minorities, women and immigrants.

speakers.name: Håvard Hvassing
speakers.shortBio: Experienced Project Manager with a demonstrated history of working in the computer software industry, working at an award-winning app agency, working with both national and international clients..

409.description:
RxSwift is a trending framework for Reactive Programming in Swift. It has been around since 2 years now and has a constant growth and new users daily.
In this workshop you will be introduced to RxSwift gradually,  starting from the basics of Observables and Subscriptions to most advanced concepts like Traits and RxCocoa.
The workshop will guide you gradually thought:
1. Intro to Observables
2. Intro to Subjects
3. Basic Operators
4. Advanced Operators
5. Intro to RxCocoa 
6. Testing with RxSwift
409.title: Reactive Programming with RxSwift

410.description:
The Kotlin programming language is developed by JetBrains and now is an officially-supported language for Android Development. This full-day workshop aims to share with you the power and the beauty of the language. We imply that you consider using Kotlin in your every-day work and want to feel more confident with the language first. We'll have a basic overview of the language, as well as the discussion of some corner cases, especially concerning Java interoperability. The workshop is based on your Java experience; it shows the similarities between two languages and focuses on what's going to be different.
We'll cover:
* Basic syntax
* Nullability
* Object-oriented programming
* Functional programming
* Java interoperability
* Building DSLs
410.title: Kotlin for Java developers

411.description: In this full-day workshop, you will learn the fundamentals of building cross-platform mobile apps targeting iOS and Android devices using React Native. React Native lets you build mobile apps using only JavaScript, without the need to use languages like Objective-C, Swift, or Java. Although you write JavaScript with React Native, the components you define will end up rendering as native widgets on the respective platforms. Hence, React Native allows you to write truly native applications, with the ease and speed of development and debugging using JavaScript.
411.title: Building Cross Platform Native Mobile Apps using React Native
